Award.AwardTitle: SusChEM: Synthesis and Characterization of Pyrite Thin Films - Towards Sustainable Photovoltaics
Award.AbstractNarration:
Technical Description: Understanding and controlling doping in pyrite iron disulfide films is a major challenge that would have significant impact towards realization of a sustainable, inexpensive, high-efficiency thin-film solar cell technology. To this end, the overarching goal of this research project is to understand and control the electronic properties of thin iron disulfide films to such an extent that fabrication of homojunction p-n solar cells is enabled. In addition to understanding electronic transport mechanisms, the research activities focus on establishing control over the charge carrier type and density by executing a detailed and systematic examination of the influence of sulfur stoichiometry and substitutional doping on the electronic properties of iron disulfide. The research team uses reactive sputtering and ex-situ sulfidation of iron films, as well as single crystal growth, to synthesize iron disulfide. The systematic research of film and crystal synthesis is accompanied by a battery of complementary characterization techniques designed to provide feedback and guidance on the effects of synthesis conditions on film properties and, in particular, on carrier densities and mobilities.

Non-technical Description: Achieving sustainable solar-to-electric energy conversion with solar cells made from inexpensive, abundant and non-toxic materials is one of the most challenging problems of the twenty-first century. While the materials dominating the current solar cell market each offer unique advantages, none are able to satisfy all of these requirements. Pyrite structure iron disulfide has been acknowledged as a sustainable material with great potential to satisfy these criteria, replacing critical materials used in the current technologies. However, control over the electronic properties of this material, which is required for efficient solar cells, has not yet been achieved. This research project aims to utilize multiple synthesis and processing strategies to achieve unprecedented control over the electronic properties in iron disulfide. This research is integrated into outreach and educational activities through interactions with the Science Museum of Minnesota, via mentoring of undergraduate students, particularly those from under-represented groups, via mentoring of high school teachers for developing science content for their classrooms, and through creation and delivery of an interactive presentation on Sustainable Materials and Chemistry designed to augment the science curriculum in the eighth grade Minneapolis Public Schools system.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Solar cells convert sunlight to electricity and reduce our dependence on burning fuels that emit carbon dioxide, a gas with high global warming potential. The global installed capacity to generate electricity using solar cells has doubled every two and a half years since 1975. Silicon solar cells with efficiencies exceeding 20% dominate the world markets and are almost solely responsible for this exponential growth. Silicon, however, is not an ideal solar cell material because it does not absorb sunlight very well, necessitating the use of thick slabs which in turn increases the material costs. Second generation solar cells on the other hand use thin films to greatly reduce the material costs. The most efficient of these thin film type solar cells are based on cadmium telluride or copper indium gallium selenide. Low abundance of indium and tellurium, and toxicity of cadmium, however, has limited the large-scale commercialization and deployment of these technologies. A sustainable commercial thin-film solar cell technology that can compete with silicon solar cells does not exist and developing one is a significant challenge. Hence, the search continues for a thin film solar cell material comprised of earth-abundant, low-cost, and non-toxic elements.

In principle, pyrite iron disulfide (also known as “fool’s gold”) satisfies all the requirements for an ideal solar cell material, at the same time having the potential to achieve efficiencies matching silicon. Both iron and sulfur are cheap and abundant. Despite this outstanding promise and decades of research, iron disulfide based solar cell efficiencies have never exceeded the disappointing value of 2.8%. No single reason for this disappointing performance has emerged but a list of puzzling issues was identified. At the top of this list was the so-called “doping puzzle,” a synecdoche for the observation that thin films and single crystals of iron disulfide appeared to conduct electric charge differently. Specifically, unintentionally doped iron disulfide thin films were claimed to almost always be p-type (positive charge carriers), in contrast to n-type behavior (negative charge carriers) exclusively seen in single crystals. Doping refers to the ability to control charge conduction via controlled introduction of impurities or defects into the material. The “doping puzzle” underscored the fundamental problem; conduction and doping mechanisms in pyrite iron disulfide were poorly understood.

Understanding and controlling doping in iron disulfide is a major challenge that would have significant impact towards realization of a sustainable, inexpensive, high-efficiency thin film solar cell technology based on iron disulfide. Towards this end, this project undertook a comprehensive and systematic investigation of doping and electronic charge transport in iron disulfide thin films and single crystals. Hall-effect and thermopower measurements on large sets of samples revealed four main findings all of which have profound implications for next steps for making solar cells based on iron disulfide. First, we found that single crystals and highest quality thin films in this study (i.e., films with highest electron mobility) are definitively n-type. Second, as the film quality and charge mobility decreases the films appear to exhibit p-type conduction. This apparent crossover to p-type behavior, however, is found to be an artifact and can be understood in terms of a crossover in charge transport mechanism, from diffusive to hopping. Third, a universal behavior is found for both single crystals and thin films, suggesting a common origin for negative charges and n-type behavior, possibly missing sulfur atoms in the crystal lattice called vacancies. Finally, the surface conduction properties of single crystals were found to be significantly different than the bulk, confirming earlier reports but also expounding upon them to demonstrate that the surface conduction is two dimensional in a region less than approximately 3 nm, and can be either p- or n-type, even dominating at room temperature.

Thus, the long-withstanding “doping puzzle” in iron disulfide has now been resolved. The supposed disagreement in majority carrier type between thin films and single crystals, “the doping puzzle,” does not really exist and earlier conclusions were likely tainted by the difficulties in making measurements in low quality films and an artifact brought about by suppression of the Hall effect due to hopping transport in low mobility films. We have found that in reality, both single crystals and high quality thin films are n-type. These conclusions have deep implications, both for interpretation of prior work on iron disulfide solar cells and for the design of future studies and solar cells. Most importantly, a majority of the previous attempts at making solar cells may have been based on the incorrect supposition that thin films are always p-type. The outcomes of this project dramatically changes the optimal approaches to designing and assembling iron disulfide solar cells, opening up completely new pathways to increase their efficiencies, possibly finally unlocking its promise and potential.
